case_name: Amar Singh v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State. He was appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked till April 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949. On that date a new State of Rajasthan was formed by the integration of a number of States including the former State of Bikaner by means of a Covenant signed by the High Contracting Parties.

facts.text: New State of Rajasthan formed on April 7, 1949 by integration including Bikaner State via Covenant.

anchor.surface_text: On that date a new State of Rajasthan was formed by the integration of a number of States including the former State of Bikaner by means of a Covenant signed by the High Contracting Parties. Article XVI 1 of the Covenant ran thus The United State hereby guarantees either the continuance in service of the permanent members of the public services of the former Rajasthan State and of each of the new Covenanting States on conditions which will not be less advantageous than those on which they were serving on the 1st November 1948 or the payment of reasonable compensation or retirement on proportionate pension.

facts.text: Article XVI of Covenant guarantees continuance in service on not less advantageous conditions than on November 1, 1948, or compensation or pension.

anchor.surface_text: Article XVI 1 of the Covenant ran thus The United State hereby guarantees either the continuance in service of the permanent members of the public services of the former Rajasthan State and of each of the new Covenanting States on conditions which will not be less advantageous than those on which they were serving on the 1st November 1948 or the payment of reasonable compensation or retirement on proportionate pension.

facts.text: Twenty eight Courts of District and Sessions Judges reduced to fifteen in integrated State.

anchor.surface_text: The integration necessarily involved a reorganisation of the various services in the several integrating States. On the judicial side it was found that there were as many as twenty eight Courts of District and Sessions Judges in the aggregate. In the integrated State it was proposed to have only fifteen.

facts.text: Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950 for provisional ad hoc postings of judicial officers.

anchor.surface_text: These arrangements are set out in a Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950. We append the relevant extracts In Appendix F have been indicated the provisional postings on an ad hoc basis of the posts specified in Appendices A to E.

facts.text: Appellant appointed ad hoc as Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in Jaipur Division per May 25, 1950 notification.

anchor.surface_text: Appendix F is headed- Ad hoc postings of Judicial Officers to Civil and Sessions Courts. The appellant was appointed under this heading in Part II as a Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in the Jaipur Division.

facts.text: On December 9, 1949, appellant transferred to Ganganagar as District and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: But before this Notification was made, namely, on December 9, 1949, the appellant received the following order from the new Rajasthan Government Shri Amar Singh, District and Sessions Judge, Churu, is transferred to Ganganagar as District and Sessions Judge, Ganganagar.

facts.text: Appellant contends December 9, 1949 order was election to continue in original post.

anchor.surface_text: Among other contentions, the appellant relies on this as an election by the new Government to continue him in his original post and contends that it could not later change its mind and make his service provisional as it purported to do in the notification just cited.

facts.text: Increment sanctioned July 31, 1950 effective March 23, 1950, raising salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580.

anchor.surface_text: Two months after the notification, namely on July 31, 1950, the appellants increment became due and Government sanctioned it in the following terms Sanction is accorded to the grant of a stipulated increment of Rs. 40 p.m. in the scale of Rs. 500-40-700 to Shri Rajvi Amarsingh, District and Sessions Judge in Bikaner Division, with effect from the 23rd March, 1950, thereby raising his salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580 p.m.

facts.text: Appellant made representation on September 11, 1950 against May 25, 1950 posting.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1950, the appellant made a representation to the Government of Rajasthan against his posting of May 25, 1950, as an ad hoc Civil and Additional Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Allegation that ad hoc postings without prejudice to claims for permanent position admitted by opposite party.

anchor.surface_text: He says in his writ petition to the High Court that he was given to understand that these ad hoc postings were without prejudice to the claims of the Government servants for a suitable position in the integrated set up on permanent basis. This allegation was admitted by the opposite party.

facts.text: Appellant appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951, Group C, No. 18, same pay grade.

anchor.surface_text: Later, he was appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951. He was placed in Group C Civil Judges and Munsiffs and placed at No. 18 in the list of junior posts. His pay and emoluments were as before and he retained the same grading, namely Rs. 500-40-700.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition on April 3, 1954 claiming entitlement to District and Sessions Judge post and violation of Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by this, the appellant filed the writ petition out of which this appeal arises on April 3, 1954. His contention was that under the guarantee given by the United State of Rajasthan, and also otherwise, he was entitled to be posted as a District and Sessions Judge in the new set up and that the posting of April 23, 1951, reduced him in rank.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court judgment dated September 5, 1955 in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954 declared April 23, 1951 appointment ad hoc and directed machinery for recruitment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the posting of April 23, 1951, which purports to appoint the appellant substantively as a Civil Judge, is wrong and that it must be treated as an ad hoc appointment till proper appointments are made to the Judicial Service of Rajasthan according to the Constitution of India. ... The petition is allowed, the postings made by notification dated the 23rd April, 1951, including that of the petitioner as Civil Judge, are declared to be on an ad hoc basis, and a direction is made to the Government to provide a machinery according to the provisions of the Constitution for the first recruitment to the Rajasthan Judicial Service. The judgment was delivered on September 5, 1955

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted on April 16, 1956 in Civil Appeal No. 330 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment was delivered on September 5, 1955, and the appellant thereupon came here and was granted special leave to appeal on April 16, 1956.

facts.text: After High Court order, Rajasthan Government complied, reframed rules, made fresh appointments published in Gazette, appellant appointed Civil Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, according to the facts set out in the respondents statement of the case, the Rajasthan Government complied with the orders of the High Court, reframed their rules and made fresh appointments in accordance with them. These were duly published in the Rajasthan Gazette and the appellant was finally selected to the Rajasthan Judicial Service. He was appointed a Civil Judge.

facts.text: Appellant contends April 23, 1951 order reduced him in rank without opportunity under Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants contention is that the order of April 23, 1951, reduced him in rank and as he was not afforded an opportunity of showing cause, Art. 311 of the Constitution was violated.

facts.text: Court holds old contracts terminate on integration, new service on new terms.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose.

facts.text: Conditions of service not less advantageous than on November 1, 1948 fulfilled for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled. ... The only guarantee assuming that the appellant can avail himself of it was that the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948.

facts.text: Rajasthan Gazette Extraordinary dated June 4, 1949 outlined integration procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This was emphasised in the Rajasthan Gazette Extraordinary dated June 4, 1949. It first referred to the broad outlines of the programme of integration that had already been published and then outlined the procedure and principles to be observed in carrying it out.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered November 28, 1957 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 28. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-This appeal arises out of a writ petition for mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Rajasthan High Court judgment dated September 5, 1955 in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954, Civil Appeal No. 330 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 330 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and decree dated September 5, 1955, of the Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954.

writ petition for mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State. He was appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949.

concepts.unlisted_label: Termination of Service Contracts on State Absorption/Integration
concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine that service contracts end when a state is absorbed, merged or integrated into another; new terms apply.

anchor.surface_text: This is nothing more, though on a more exalted scale, than an application of the principle that underlies the law of Master and Servant when there is a change of masters.

concepts.interpretation: Underlies the rule on service termination upon change of sovereignty/government.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rules and made fresh appointments in accordance with them. These were duly published in the Rajastha

concepts.unlisted_label: Master and Servant Principle on Change of Masters
concepts.unlisted_description: Common law principle applied analogously to public service on change of employing authority.

anchor.surface_text: So far as this Court is concerned, the law is settled by the decision in The, State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan 1 , which follows the decisions of the Privy Council and the House of Lords in Reilly v. The King 2 , and Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd. 3 . The distinction between rights to property and contractual rights when there is a change of sovereignty was pointed out in Virendra Singh others v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 4 .

concepts.interpretation: Distinction exists between property rights and contractual (service) rights upon change of sovereignty.

concepts.unlisted_label: Distinction between Property Rights and Contractual Rights on Change of Sovereignty
concepts.unlisted_description: Rights to property survive change of sovereignty unlike pure contractual rights.

holdings.text: when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well established law settled by State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan following Privy Council and House of Lords decisions in Reilly v. The King and Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.

holdings.text: Article XVI 1 indicates that the old contracts terminate just as they did in The State Of Madras K. M. Rajagopalan. In the first place, there were three options continuance in service, payment of reasonable compensation, and retirement on proportionate pension. That shows that the old contracts terminated and that those who continued in service did so on the basis of fresh contracts

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled. ... The only guarantee assuming that the appellant can avail himself of it was that the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948. There was no guarantee that they would be the same or better. This was emphasised in the Rajasthan Gazette Extraordinary dated June 4, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three options in Article XVI 1 show termination of old contracts and new terms; only guarantee is conditions not less advantageous

holdings.text: the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948. We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled. ... The only guarantee assuming that the appellant can avail himself of it was that the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948.

But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-integration appointments temporary pending reorganisation and rules; first substantive post as Civil Judge either in 1951 or later after High Court order

An order of transfer cannot be equated to an order of appointment and in any case, the new cadres had not been established

holdings.reasoning_summary: Description incidental in increment order; endorsement shows current posting; not fixation of permanent cadre

The petition is allowed, the postings made by notification dated the 23rd April, 1951, including that of the petitioner as Civil Judge, are declared to be on an ad hoc basis,

anchor.surface_text: But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. edges.explanation: holding h1 addresses the issue i3 by stating contracts automatically terminate

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose.

But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary and so far as Art. XVI 1 of the Covenant is concerned, its guarantee has been fulfilled.

edges.explanation: h2's analysis of Article XVI(1) options and termination supports h3's fulfillment of not less advantageous conditions
Holding h2 interprets Article XVI(1) options and termination of old contracts, addressing whether new conditions violated the guarantee in i2

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled. ... The only guarantee assuming that the appellant can avail himself of it was that the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948. There was no guarantee that they would be the same or better. This was emphasised in the Rajasthan Gazette Extraordinary dated June 4, 1949.

But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary and so far as Art. XVI 1 of the Covenant is concerned, its guarantee has been fulfilled.

All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the posting of April 23, 1951, which purports to appoint the appellant substantively as a Civil Judge, is wrong and that it must be treated as an ad hoc appointment till proper appointments are made to the Judicial Service of Rajasthan according to the Constitution of India. ... The petition is allowed, the postings made by notification dated the 23rd April, 1951, including that of the petitioner as Civil Judge, are declared to be on an ad hoc basis,
